Award.AwardTitle: Mass Spectrometry and Computational Studies of Deprotonated Substituted Peptides
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Carolyn Cassady and Professor David Dixon and their groups will study the gas-phase reactive and dissociative chemistry of deprotonated amino acids, their amides, and peptides by mass spectrometry and computational techniques. The primary focus will be on acidic residues that readily deprotonate, such as phosphorylated serine, tyrosine, and threonine, as well as aspartic acid and glutamic acid. An overall goal is to increase the knowledge of deprotonated peptide fragmentation mechanisms, ion structures, and acid/base properties so that proteomics researchers seeking to sequence peptides by negative ion mass spectrometry will have a strong foundation of fundamental information upon which to base their work. This research will further the development of new methods of analysis of peptides using negative ion mode tandem mass spectrometry, with particular emphasis being placed on electron-based dissociation techniques for sequencing acidic peptides.

This project exposes a diverse group of both graduate and undergraduate students to important interdisciplinary research areas, providing them with tools that will prepare them to contribute to a wide range of proteomic and chemical biology challenges. Both groups are also been actively engaged in outreach activities, such as the University of Alabama Computer Based Honors Program and the Alabama Advanced Instrumental Techniques Colloquium, which expose large numbers of students to the powerful computational and analytical tools utilized in their laboratories.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mass spectrometry (MS) is an important tool in the analysis of peptides. However, the conventional methods involve protonation, leading to preferential analysis of basic peptides.  Acidic peptides, which contain carboxylic acid or phospho side chains, can be very difficult to analyze using positive ion protonated MS.  Yet, a knowledge of acidic peptide sequence is important in a variety of areas, including fundamental studies of biological processes, understanding protein structure and function in the Human Proteome Project, and the development of biotechnology tools for diverse fields such as human health and forensic analysis.  Acidic peptides readily deprotonate and therefore can be studied by negative ion MS.  The overall goal of this project was to increase the knowledge of deprotonated peptide fragmentation mechanisms, ion structures, and acid/base properties so that researchers seeking to sequence acidic peptides will have a strong foundation of fundamental information upon which to base their work.  An additional goal was to further the development of peptide analysis methods using negative ion tandem MS (MS/MS).  This research employed a combination of experiments and high level molecular orbital theory calculations.

One specific goal was to determine the gas-phase acidities (GAs) of amino acids, their amides, and small acidic peptides.  This provided information on the sites of the negative charge in gas-phase ions, which is important to the understanding of fragmentation pathways and peptide sequencing by MS.  In a continuation of work from our prior NSF grant, the amino acid tyrosine and its corresponding amide were extensively studied.  It was found that deprotonated tyrosine exists in three unique gas-phase structures (see Figure 1):  one structure deprotonated at the phenolic side chain and two structures deprotonated at the carboxylic acid C-terminus with different conformations (shapes).  The conditions employed in ion formation by electospray ionization were found to affect structures, which is an important consideration for researchers in the field.  This was the first report of three unique structures for a small biological anion.  Proton transfer reactions and calculations were also used to determine the GAs of the common amino acid amides for the first time.  These values are important because such amides serve as models for residues in peptides and proteins.  For compounds whose most acidic site is the C-terminal amide nitrogen, two ion populations were found with GAs differing by 4-7 kcal/mol (see Figure 2).  These values are already being used by researchers seeking to explain their experimental results in applied situations.  In addition, the GAs of the phospho amino acids and their amides were determined.   Phosphorylation is the most common biological modification in proteins and is crucial to function.  Because of their high acidities, these phospho compounds have only one deprotonation site; however, analysis conditions again affects shape.

Another goal was to explore fragmentation mechanisms of peptides using the common technique of collision-induced dissociation (CID) with the unique aspect being the negative ion mode.  To increase the understanding of bond cleavage during MS/MS, bond dissociation energy (BDE) calculations obtained with mono-, di-, and tri-peptides were compared to MS/MS spectra (see Figure 3).  The lowest energy processes were favored, although some computationally predicted processes did not occur experimentally.  An interesting aspect was elimination of water from peptide amides, even though their structures have no -OH group.  Experiments were performed on small model peptides containing highly acidic phospo residues.  Both the position and the identity of the residue had a strong impact on dissociation.  Diagnostic ions were identified that allow identification of the phospho group.

The third intellectual goal of this project was to explore radical-based dissociation for acidic peptides and compare the fragmentation patterns and sequence information obtained to that of more conventional CID.  For acidic peptides with more than 20 residues, the most informative technique was in-source decay (nISD), where energy for bond cleavage was provided by an irradiating laser.  This is the first time that the technique was extensively employed on negative ions (see Figure 4).  For peptides with 20 or fewer residues, negative electron transfer dissociation (NETD) was found to be most informative.  Both nISD and NETD provide more information about sequence than negative mode CID.  Radical-based techniques were shown to be a promising tool for acidic peptide analysis.

Regarding additional broader impacts, training was provided for numerous students in MS and computational techniques.  The primary graduate student researcher in the computational studies obtained her PhD and is employed in teaching chemistry and physics, while the primary MS researcher obtained her PhD and works as an MS applications scientist.  Two graduate students whose research focuses on this project will be moving into the MS job market within the next few years.  Six former undergraduate researchers are now obtaining graduate degrees in chemistry/biochemistry or medical degrees.  This project has exposed other undergraduates to MS and computational chemistry through outreach activities such as the Advanced Instrumental Techniques Colloquium.

Modified by: Carolyn J Cassady

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Mass spectrometry (MS) is an important tool in the analysis of peptides. However, the conventional methods involve protonation, leading to preferential analysis of basic peptides. Acidic peptides, which contain carboxylic acid or phospho side chains, can be very difficult to analyze using positive ion protonated MS. Yet, a knowledge of acidic peptide sequence is important in a variety of areas, including fundamental studies of biological processes, understanding protein structure and function in the Human Proteome Project, and the development of biotechnology tools for diverse fields such as human health and forensic analysis. Acidic peptides readily deprotonate and therefore can be studied by negative ion MS. The overall goal of this project was to increase the knowledge of deprotonated peptide fragmentation mechanisms, ion structures, and acid/base properties so that researchers seeking to sequence acidic peptides will have a strong foundation of fundamental information upon which to base their work. An additional goal was to further the development of peptide analysis methods using negative ion tandem MS (MS/MS). This research employed a combination of experiments and high level molecular orbital theory calculations. One specific goal was to determine the gas-phase acidities (GAs) of amino acids, their amides, and small acidic peptides. This provided information on the sites of the negative charge in gas-phase ions, which is important to the understanding of fragmentation pathways and peptide sequencing by MS. In a continuation of work from our prior NSF grant, the amino acid tyrosine and its corresponding amide were extensively studied. It was found that deprotonated tyrosine exists in three unique gas-phase structures (see Figure 1): one structure deprotonated at the phenolic side chain and two structures deprotonated at the carboxylic acid C-terminus with different conformations (shapes). The conditions employed in ion formation by electospray ionization were found to affect structures, which is an important consideration for researchers in the field. This was the first report of three unique structures for a small biological anion. Proton transfer reactions and calculations were also used to determine the GAs of the common amino acid amides for the first time. These values are important because such amides serve as models for residues in peptides and proteins. For compounds whose most acidic site is the C-terminal amide nitrogen, two ion populations were found with GAs differing by 4-7 kcal/mol (see Figure 2). These values are already being used by researchers seeking to explain their experimental results in applied situations. In addition, the GAs of the phospho amino acids and their amides were determined. Phosphorylation is the most common biological modification in proteins and is crucial to function. Because of their high acidities, these phospho compounds have only one deprotonation site; however, analysis conditions again affects shape. Another goal was to explore fragmentation mechanisms of peptides using the common technique of collision-induced dissociation (CID) with the unique aspect being the negative ion mode. To increase the understanding of bond cleavage during MS/MS, bond dissociation energy (BDE) calculations obtained with mono-, di-, and tri-peptides were compared to MS/MS spectra (see Figure 3). The lowest energy processes were favored, although some computationally predicted processes did not occur experimentally. An interesting aspect was elimination of water from peptide amides, even though their structures have no -OH group. Experiments were performed on small model peptides containing highly acidic phospo residues. Both the position and the identity of the residue had a strong impact on dissociation. Diagnostic ions were identified that allow identification of the phospho group. The third intellectual goal of this project was to explore radical-based dissociation for acidic peptides and compare the fragmentation patterns and sequence information obtained to that of more conventional CID. For acidic peptides with more than 20 residues, the most informative technique was in-source decay (nISD), where energy for bond cleavage was provided by an irradiating laser. This is the first time that the technique was extensively employed on negative ions (see Figure 4). For peptides with 20 or fewer residues, negative electron transfer dissociation (NETD) was found to be most informative. Both nISD and NETD provide more information about sequence than negative mode CID. Radical-based techniques were shown to be a promising tool for acidic peptide analysis. Regarding additional broader impacts, training was provided for numerous students in MS and computational techniques. The primary graduate student researcher in the computational studies obtained her PhD and is employed in teaching chemistry and physics, while the primary MS researcher obtained her PhD and works as an MS applications scientist. Two graduate students whose research focuses on this project will be moving into the MS job market within the next few years. Six former undergraduate researchers are now obtaining graduate degrees in chemistry/biochemistry or medical degrees. This project has exposed other undergraduates to MS and computational chemistry through outreach activities such as the Advanced Instrumental Techniques Colloquium.
